INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES

As arrangements have now been completed for the installation of Electric Power Services on the Garden River Reserve, I obtained estimates on wiring the Roman Catholic and Anglican Schools, which I am enclosing.

As it will take some time to obtain the electrical material required, kindly advise me if it will be in order to proceed with the wiring of these two schools.

R.P.G. Laurence
Indian Agent
Sault Ste. Marie Ontario.

RFGL/cwc
Ottawa, July 30, 1946.

Mr. R.P.G. Laurence, Indian Agent, Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

I have your letter of the 19th instant, enclosing estimates for the wiring of the Garden River R.C. and the Garden River C.E. Schools.

Do the prices quoted include the wiring of the living quarters occupied by the teachers of these schools?

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
August 2nd, 1946.

INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES.

In reply to your letter file 30013-8 (W.T.I) dated 30th July 1946, I beg to advise that the price quoted includes the wiring of the living quarters occupied by the teachers of the Garden River R.C. and C.E. Schools.

R.P.G. Laurence
Indian Agent
Sault Ste. Marie Ontario.

RPGL/cwc
Ottawa, August 8, 1946.

Mr. R.F.G. Laurence, Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

With reference to your letters of the 19th ultimo and 2nd instant, the Department approves the installation of electric power services in the Garden River R.C. and the Garden River C.E. Schools and teachers' residences.

It is understood that the cost of installing electricity in the Garden River C.E. School and residence will be $183.30 and in the Garden River R.C. School and residence, $219.00.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES.

The wiring of the Garden River R.C., Anglican Schools and teachers quarters, have been completed in accordance with instructions contained in your letter, file 13-2-5 W.T. l. dated August 8th, 1946.

It is now necessary to arrange for the purchase of fixtures for same. The cost for labour and installing of fixtures in the school rooms and living quarters for the R.C. School will be approximately $170.00, and the cost for the Anglican School rooms and living quarters will be approximately $121.00. The school room fixtures are standard equipment and the fixtures for the living quarters are inexpensive fittings.

Kindly advise me if it will be in order to have the necessary fixtures installed.

R.P.G. Laurence
Indian Agent
Sault Ste. Marie Ontario.

DATE: Oct. 25, 1946

Agent
The Anglican School,
Garden River, Ont.

Mr. R.P.H. Lawrence,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie.

Dear Sir:

In making requisition for soup for the twenty-five pupils at this school I am asking that it start on Nov. 1st, the same as in former years and continue until March 31st. These five months are the coldest.

Last year we got 6¢ per head for this service. The ingredients alone cost 5¢ per month leaving us 60¢ for our work. We are asking that we be allowed 8¢ per month this year. We serve soup off beef bones and make it thick with plenty of vegetables, rice, barley or macaroni. The Inspector last winter was quite pleased with it.

Yours truly,

Albert E. Smith

October 23rd, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch

Department of Mines and Resources

You will please find enclosed letter received from Mr. A.E. Smith, teacher of the Garden River C.E. School, requesting that he be allowed $8.00 per month, this year instead of $6.00 for supplying hot lunches to the 25 pupils attending his school, to start on November 1st, and continuing to March 31st.

For your information the Garden River R.C. School, with an attendance of 75 pupils, is allowed $12.00 per month for hot lunches from December 1st, to March 31st.

Kindly advise me regarding this matter at your convenience.

R.F.G. Laurence
Indian Agent
Sault Ste. Marie Ontario.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I wish to acknowledge your letter of Aug. 19th, file 13-2-5 (W.T.I) regarding requisition from the Garden River Anglican School with reference to stoves and water supply.

Two new stoves are required for this school, one for the classroom and one for the teacher's residence as the present stoves are old and worn out. Mr. Smith would like to get two "Air-circulating" wood stoves to replace the old ones. The cost of these stoves would be approximately $50.00 each. I recommend that this request be granted.

With reference to the water supply, at present Mr. Smith has to carry his drinking and washing water about 700 feet.

The water that was formerly used at this school is full of iron and corrodes all the water pails, etc. Mr. Smith will not use this water.

Three years ago the Department tried to obtain a new source of water for this school, but it was not a success. I am getting further advice regarding this matter and will notify you at a later date what I think should be done to improve the water supply for this school.

R. P. G. Laurence,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

Classroom Inspection Report -
Garden River C.E. Indian Day School.

Mr. A.E. Smith, age forty-six, fourteen years Indian experience, twelve years Provincial Experience.

Enrolment is as follows:

| Grade | Enrolment |
|-------|-----------|
| 1     | 7         |
| 2     | 6         |
| 3     | 4         |
| 5     | 3         |
| 6     | 4         |
| 7     | 2         |

The attendance on February 3rd, the day on which I inspected this school was sixteen. I tested only Grade 5 and Grade 7 with Achievement Tests and found them good in Spelling and weak in English and especially in Arithmetic.

This teacher seems to be in a rut and I feel that a change is definitely indicated. He admits frankly that he has lost interest in the lower grades and would like to handle the Senior Room at a two-room school. He is quite willing to move if we so request.

Discipline is no problem and the children are well mannered. They work well on their own and speak out well. The room is very untidy. In a corner is a work bench which takes up quite a bit of room (see recommendations below). The teacher was unshaven and his appearance left much to be desired in the way of cleanliness and tidiness.
This school is about fifty years old and has a large brick fireplace in the front of the room. This cuts down the blackboard surface considerably. The teacher's quarters are made up of a kitchen, dining-room/sitting-room at the back. The whole is lighted with electricity and is adequately wired. The classroom has six semi-indirect lights in the ceiling.

RECOMMENDATIONS:

1. A brooder house at the back of the school should be fixed up as small workshop and the Manual Training equipment should be moved to it. There is an old stove which can be quite easily put up in the workshop. It could also be used as a small storeroom for Scout and Guide supplies.

2. During 1949-50 we should have an Engineer visit the school and decide what can be done about the foundation. The building seems sound in spite of its age. The present teacher and the Agent seem to feel that the foundation could be dug behind the school and that the building could be moved back to this new foundation. We could then arrange to have it heated by a furnace and at the same time remove the brick fireplace.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Mr. R.P.G. Laurence,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir,

Last fall I wrote asking you to ask the Department for ten dollars a month for supplying a hot dish to the pupils of this school. Your reply stated that only $6.00 a month would be allowed.

You might write to the Department and ask them to raise the amount to ten dollars for the five months when we serve soup or cocoa.

You and they must know that the cost of living has raised in the last few years. You must realize that we serve an average of 20 bowls of soup a day for 20 days in the month which gives us approximately a cent and a half a bowl. If we can serve soup at that price and break even we are wasting our time here. We should be in the restaurant business.

While we were in the Oka Indian School we were paid ten dollars a month. We had only 10 or 12 children with us for lunch while here we have all 20. And that was in the depression years when food was about half what it is now.

Six dollars a month allows us 30 cents a day. Milk is 16 cents a quart. It takes at least two quarts of milk for the cocoa. Now what should we use for money to buy the cocoa, vanilla, sugar, and butter which are all necessary.

I am sure you can see that we are losing money on this project and still we have met the heart to refuse because we know that the hot dish is necessary for them.

Yours truly,

A.E. Smith

I am enclosing plans which I have drawn to illustrate my idea of having indoor toilets placed in this school at as early a date as possible, preferably this summer.

On sheet 1 I have drawn a plan of the school and porch as it is. There is no need for a four foot door and a door this size is frightfully cold. I would have the porch removed altogether and an 8 foot addition built on the front of the school. As shown on sheet 2 this addition would be divided into three parts each 7'x8'. The centre room to be used as storage space while the two side rooms would be used as toilet and cloak-rooms.

This would cost in the neighbourhood of $1000 but it should be done as the children have to wade through snow a distance of 75 yards to the outdoor toilets.

DIRECTOR, LANDS and DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH

Garden River C.E. Indian Day School -

The Anglican Indian Day School at Garden River is situated some ten miles from Sault Ste. Marie on the highway. It is a very old building but is soundly constructed and should serve our needs for some years to come. However, there is need for moving the building to a proper foundation as the present one is crumbling. We have now received a letter from Mr. A. E. Smith, the present teacher, forwarded by Mr. Indian Superintendent Laurence. Mr. Smith's letter reads as follows:

"I am enclosing plans which I have drawn to illustrate my idea of having indoor toilets placed in this school at as early a date as possible, preferably this summer.

"This would cost in the neighbourhood of $1000 but it should be done as the children have to wade through snow a distance of 75 yards to the outdoor toilets.

onto it or excavate under the school where it is and put in a basement where the toilets could be installed. Either of these plans would be much better but would run into higher expense."

We are attaching his drawings to illustrate his recommendations.

Our Superintendent of Education recently inspected this school and reports that action is definitely needed if we are to save this building. Unfortunately, it is a two-storey building with the teachers'age being over the classroom. It would be appreciated if we could have an engineer visit this school and recommend the action that is needed to either

(a) preserve this building, or

(b) decide whether we should erect a new school.

I would suggest that the engineer sent to Sault Ste. Marie check first with our Superintendent of Education, who will be able to provide further details.

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, October 5, 1948.

Re: Protestant Indian Day School,
Garden River, Ontario.

Further to our memorandum of July 7th, you are advised that our Mr. Hargreaves visited the above on September 16th, on his way back from a trip through the West, and the following report is submitted for your information and transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch.

It is estimated that the building is at least 50 years old. It appears to be structurally sound, but the windows and doors are noticeably loose fitting. The building is located 55 feet from the main highway.

The classroom, is 29'-3" long x 21' wide with a 9 foot ceiling which is somewhat smaller than a standard classroom of modern design. There are seats for twenty-two pupils and at present there is an attendance of twenty-nine pupils with at least thirty-four expected next year.

The first floor, in addition to the classroom, has a kitchen 10'-6" x 10'-6" and a dining room 9'-6" x 15'-6" and a small pantry. The second floor has five (5) average size bedrooms and a small lavatory which contains a chemical toilet. The building is heated by stoves.

There is a shallow well with a hand pump, on the property south of the building, and it was noticed that the water has an oily scum and is unpalatable. There is also a deep well casing near the school which is capped. Should it be desired to use this deep well, it would be necessary to "blow" the casing and remove some sand which has found its way into the pipe. The water from this well is said to be of good quality.

It would be possible to establish a sewage disposal field southwest of the building to serve a plumbing system, if one were installed.

If a new basement were excavated and built on a site immediately south of the existing building as has been suggested, and the building moved and set up thereon, together with the installation of plumbing, water supply and heating, it is estimated that the sum of $10,000.00 would be required to carry out these operations.

After having given careful consideration to the foregoing proposal, it is felt that it would be un-economical to carryout such operations. Nothing would be gained relative to bringing the classroom up to reasonably modern design. In view of the fact that a new modern one room school with basement and teachers' quarters, together with mechanical services, could be erected for approximately $15,000.00, it is recommended that the Indian Affairs Branch give consideration to this suggestion.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I wish to acknowledge your letter of October 28th, 1948, file 389-5 (E.1) regarding letter received by the Department from Mrs. Frances Solomon, Secretary of the Garden River Women's Institute, requesting that in the interests of health the children in the schools be supplied with one pint of milk and one orange each day.

The present cost to the Department of supplying this Agency with vitamin biscuits and provisions for hot drinks is approximately $2,000.00 per year. To supply the pupils of each school with a pint of milk and an orange each day would cost approximately $6,500.00 per year, which is quite an item.

I would suggest that a few extra dollars per month be allowed each school to make hot soup as the present allowance for this purpose is not sufficient due to the high cost of food.

If the pupils receive the biscuits and a hot cup of soup each day, I would then feel that the Department has done their share and if any milk is needed it should be supplied by the parents from their family allowance cheques.

Dear Sir,

Writing to you this letter, I do not speak in my own name but for... and as the representative of... the great majority of the Indians belonging to the Stingwater Band.

Months ago, one of them who is a councillor came and asked me whether it was right that the protestant schoolteacher be paid with the money of the Catholics. "No," I replied, "it is not right; no more than it would be to take in your pocket your money to support the family of another." — "But," he said, "we never consented to it." — "Then," I answered, "it is evidently against the first principles of justice."

After some time, the new protestant teacher, who is at the same time the minister, took charge of the school. Another man told me then that this protestant teacher and minister was supported by the 300 dollars paid by the band, which is however two-thirds catholic.

And again and again people came to talk about the matter.

Of course, dear sir, a long time before the first of them opened his mouth about it to me, I wondered at the extraordinary state of affairs which became the object of their complaint. — Why, when all sensible people in Canada are now indignant at the unfair treatment of the Catholic minority by an oppressive and dynastic majority in Manitoba; when...
most especially, the conservative party is ready to fight in favor of the persecuted minority of this province; ... in the same Canada, and in a village that depends directly for its administration on the conservative government of Ottawa, it is a majority, Catholic, which is robbed of its money and its rights in favor of a protestant minority! There, in Manitoba, it is the Catholics have been obliged to pray for the protestant schools; but, after all, they are the minority, which gives to narrow-minded and bigoted people a bad excuse for the fact; but here, for many years already, the Catholics, although being the great majority, have been obliged to pray for the protestant school! — The case in Manitoba is an enormous injustice; the case in Ganton River, is it not, besides, exceedingly unreasonable ...?

One might say: "This is clear enough; but why did they not send their protestation before now?" To which question I might answer: "It does not matter. The right is clear enough, and there is no prescription against Indian rights." — But I say, they did not yet protest because they are a peaceable kind of people, and would not make any noise as long as they did not see in the other party the spirit of animosity with which they seem to be inspired since the last election of the chief; — Because also they did not yet appreciate as they do now these advantages of education, and one teacher
paid by another band was sufficient for the number of children who came to school; now it is all different—last year, and this year, most especially in the fall and spring, often 50 children are present and almost always over 40, so that it becomes, if not absolutely necessary, at least very desirable to have a second teacher; and consequently they want now to use their own money for the benefit of their own children.

Now, our people wish to be well understood. They do not desire to suppress the protestant school. They would be pleased to see the protestant children well educated, but their conscience will not allow them to contribute their money to the support of a protestant teacher and minister;... besides what I said already, that they intend using their own means for their own benefit. All others do the same.

Now, dear sir, I send you a copy of the petition that they wish to be sent to you, and to which they added their names:

"We, the undersigned, and our friends Catholic of Garden River Reserve protest—against the use made of our Indian money to support the teacher of the Protestant school, where we, being the great majority, would not send our children. Our money, if used for school purposes,
ought to go to the Catholic school where a second teacher is wanted.

Besides, as we heard, that some of the money of our band was to be given to a Protestant minister who would come here regularly or stay here, protest again against that; and we hope that the officers of the Department will keep us under these circumstances as justice requires.

Rev: Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 29th ultimo relative to the mode of paying the salaries of the teachers of the two Garden River Indian schools, I have the honor to refer you to official letter of the 10th July 1896 on this subject, which the Department considers fully meets the case in point, which is not one of rights of majorities or minorities, but simply a matter of account. The Garden River Indians as the wealthier of the two bands is assessed $300, while the Batchewana Band contributes $200, and this contribution of $500 towards the salaries of the teachers of the two schools, is supplemented by a grant of $100, making $600 in all for this purpose which is divided between the two schools.

In regard to the question of a salary for a second teacher, I beg to refer you to official letter of the 9th April last in which you were informed that the Department would consent to pay for an average attendance over 25 and up to 42, after the 30th June last, if Estimates voted. As, however, the present year's estimates have not yet been voted, nothing can at present be done in this matter.

In conclusion I may add that neither the Indians or the Department contribute anything to the Protestant minister on this Reserve.

Dear Sir:

Please refer to your letters 15328 and 15328-5 of April and July 1896, and answer of July 21st. I write again about the salary for the Roman Catholic school.

In reply to my last letter you kindly said that Mr. Van Alst was going to send a report on the matter. More than two months elapsed since then; I suppose that the Agent had time enough to forward the information required. It may be mistaken however, as the old gentleman is always sick. But is a report necessary when a petition bearing the names of the great majority of the Indians of this band has been sent to the Department, in a case where there can be no doubt whether the claims are right or not, as they are founded upon the very words of the law in the most evident manner?

After having taken these years long, every means and much trouble to obtain that the children be regular at school, I have been successful and raised our average to 37 for the past quarter; without average would be about 45 if the two first weeks, all 37 had come back from the fields. Upon every day, when there is a good weather, we have 50 scholars, and I expect to have yet more of them present. But one condition is indispensable: I must have a second teacher.

It may be that in the Provincial schools teachers are expected to teach up to 45 pupils; but whoever has any idea of our Indian schools knows that they are much more difficult to manage than the white ones.

Already, dear sir, in your letter of July 21st, you stated that you consent...
to pay us for an average attendance over 25 and up to 42. 5 dollars per quarter for each child over 25. Consequently, the estimates having been voted now, I expect to receive for the next quarter $115 instead of $75, and so on each quarter.

But, dear sir, see the inconvenience of that manner of payment in our case. Assuredly, if nothing extraordinary happens; if the weather is not too stormy, if there is no sickness among the children, the average will be over 42, and I shall receive from the Department an amount which will allow me to pay two teachers. But if anything occurs and keeps at home 10 or 15 of them, there will be no money to pay the second teacher.

And if I have only one teacher, as he cannot possibly teach properly so many pupils in different standards, we will see unavoidably the average decrease little by little.

Please let your Department remember that after and with religion the best way to improve the condition of our Indians is the school; and when after 3 years of experience you see a place where so much is done with success in that way, do, I pray, whatever is possible to help it. For many years, the missioners purchased the schoolbuilding with the whole furniture; we contributed again $25 towards the erection of the new one and paid 30 dollars for the assurance of it; we are yet building a large shed for the children 60 x 25; after promising efforts we are obtaining a very fair average of presence; what more forward ought not to be stopped? And what less if you is only to give me for once the 200
dollars that according to every probability will have to be paid conformably to your letter of July the 7th (without that I can find no teacher.)

And the Indian Act gives you an easy way to get the money. The R. Catholics being the great majority in Mingan River Band, that band ought to pay at least 200 for a R. Catholic teacher. These 200 added to the 300 paid by the Badjowanang Band and the general fund, will afford the 500 required. What our people is asking for is nothing but that, and every impartial mind could not but approve of it.

P.S. Dear Sir, answer promptly this letter, because we are all very anxious to see at once our second teacher; I am almost sure to find one now with good certificates.

I remain, Dear Sir,

Your servant in the Lord,

J. A. Orton

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of July 8th, I beg to say that there is no truth in the statement that the school here is to be conducted by the nuns in future. It was never questioned sometime ago of coming here, but it also was decided long ago that they would not come.

The Indians state that they are perfectly satisfied with Mr. Reid. I do not know where they took their information, very likely in the same source where they took that the nuns were to conduct the school in future. Acting on the hint left to the church to nominate the teacher, I must say that His Lordship, Right Reverend R. A. O'Connell, D.D., Bishop of Peterborough, the Bishop of this Diocese, is opposed to Mr. Reid's nomination or reengagement as school teacher for another year.

I can also refer you to the School Inspector Mr. J. F. White, who is not satisfied with his success. Here is what he wrote to me on June 22nd 1901:

"I regret to know that Mr. Reid is again giving you..."
trouble about retaining his position. He will not, however, gain much if he appeals to the Indian Department as our reports on his success would not strengthen his case."

At his visit here in June, Mr. White also spoke to me and quite approved of a change, and he also spoke the same way to others. With these two authorities, I thought I was justified in looking for other teachers in hopes of having better satisfaction.

Mr. Reid's daughter told me when she left here at the end of the year, that she would never come back. So this changes the position of Mr. Reid. That same girl has been complaining to me during the two years she has been here, that she was not getting enough of salary.

It is recognized that I am responsible for the school and I also have many reasons for a change. Mr. Reid would not follow my direction; see for instance, it took him 17 days to make the Return of the last quarter, though the regulations of the Department are that these Returns are to be sent in immediately after the end of the Quarter. Also I never could get Mr. Reid to let the children out at four o'clock; parents were often complaining of it, and I also had to complain about it for this particular reason. Every day, morning and evening, I have to take some of the children across the Garden River in a boat.
or have a man to do it for me. The children of one class would come out at 4:30 and the man and children had to wait 15 or even 25 minutes before the children of Mr. Reid's class would come out. I also often noticed that he would begin school at 8:15 minutes after 1 o'clock, the same in the morning.

For Mr. Reid's daughter she has been repeating me right along that she would not come back, even at the beginning of the year. She began to say she was sorry she had come. For her she is out of the question for me, as she had given me notice herself, and I never told her of the notice I had given her father. Both father and daughter could not agree together, how could I get a stranger to agree with Mr. Reid.

Chief Michael Cadette who has also received a letter from acknowledging receipt of the petition of July 11th, told me this morning that he did not sign nor allow any one to put his name on a petition to retain Mr. Reid's services. There has been too many petitions made on this Reserve lately, and we can pretty near guess who was at the bottom of them. Before giving notice to Mr. Reid I spoke to the Indian agent, Mr. Wm. Abbott, and he was quite satisfied of the change. He might tell you something himself about Mr. Reid.
Under the direction of our Bishop and the approval of the school Inspector and the consent of the Agent and chief of Garden River Band I acted in good faith and for the good of the school in giving notice to Mr. Reid. He knew or ought to know that his position is changed since his daughter has decided not to come back, and he never asked me himself to reengage him, even after the conditions were changed. The Indians never spoke to me about it, though on June 14th they sent me a petition or rather a summons to retain Mr. Reid's services. They gave me only six hours to comply with the request, and after the six hours they wrote to the Department to do so at once.

Some of the Indians whose names appeared on that petition told me they were sorry they had signed the petition, the chief himself declared in writing before a witness that he had been deceived when they asked him to put his name. He does not want to retain his services, though somebody has put his name on the petition. I have already been too long, and I could say much more, I wanted to give as full information as possible. Hoping this will be satisfactory and that the question will soon be settled, to allow me to secure
Teachers for August the 15th, the opening of the school. With this delay and so late, I am afraid I may not be able to have the teachers who have made applications. It is not my intention to act against Our Bishop's direction, nor the School Inspector's advice and it is not question for the nuns coming here to conduct the school.

I remain, Dear Sir,

Your humble servant

H. Caron

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MISS DAVY, TEACHER OF THE GARDEN RIVER B.C.

DAY SCHOOL.

The attendance is all that could be desired during the last and first quarters of the year. Many of the children come from French Bay, a distance of 2½ miles and these never start back after the Christmas vacation, until the end of March. I would suggest that for the winter quarter one of the teachers teach in the Bay. A small room fitted up temporarily would be all that would be necessary for the three months. Both class rooms are heated here and only pupils for one. Let this second fire be kept in vacant house or room in the Bay. This of course only for three winter months. For the remainder of the term, the present conditions are excellent. One teacher for the junior and one for the senior room is a much better arrangement than the two teachers with a class of junior and senior pupils in different schools.

IS JANITOR'S WORK PERFORMED IN A SATISFACTORY MANNER? Not so well as would be desired.
Separate School, Teacher, Miss Margaret Darby.

Pupils in section of school age 70.

On roll, Senior, 31
Junior, 22

Average 17

This school is without the teacher's manuals, they also are without any kind of books on nature study.

I would recommend that the Ont. Teachers Manuals be sent, also Comstock's Manual of Nature Study.

The pupils are bright, they seem to be progressing splendidly with the present teacher.

They are planning to have gardens at home, also at the school this year.

The wood for the schools should be cut one year ahead, green wood makes poor wood and it takes more than if seasoned.

English School, Teacher, L. T. Hardyman.

Pupils in section of school age 30

On roll 19
Present 9

In grade 3 there are 2
2 5
1 11

There are no pupils in the 4th grade.

Although Mr. Hardyman has been in this school for 15 yrs. he has not, as yet, had a single pupil in grade 4.

I am of the opinion that a new teacher should be engaged. My reasons are as follows:

(1) Mr. Hardyman is not a competent teacher, has never had any training as a teacher.

(2) He is very sloshy about the school, often is not properly dressed.
REPORT ON SASKATCHEWAN RIVER AGENCY.

BY R.M. Abraham, B.B.A.

(3) He has the school closed much too often, I am told by a reliable white man that often the school is closed 2 days a week.

(4) He is at present paying marked attention to an Indian girl of questionable character and the Indians are talking.

(5) He has adequate private means to live on.

(6) The parents refuse to send their children to him.

I believe a suitable boarding place could be found for a lady teacher at Mr. Addys, the store keeper.

I interviewed Inspector Green regarding Mr. Hardyman's work in the school. He admitted that he is a poor teacher not a competent teacher, but said that he had no other school where he could place such a poor teacher. He said that he didn't think the Indian Dept. required a very high standard.

I would recommend that the truant officer be instructed to prosecute parents who refuse to send their children to school. The attendance is very poor, as you will see.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Agent McNabb forwards the resignation of Miss Jean McDermott, assistant teacher at the Garden River (R.C.) Indian Day School, to take effect at the end of the present quarter, and enclosed a doctor's certificate stating that she is permanently unable to carry on the duties of school teacher. Miss McDermott requests that, in view of her long service, she be granted super-annuation. There is no provision for the granting of superannuation to teachers of Indian day schools, but a gratuity on retirement has been granted in the case of several teachers in the past.

Miss McDermott has been in the employ of the Department since 1908, having first been engaged as teacher of the Goulais Bay School. She was transferred to the Garden Village School, Sturgeon Falls Agency, after the summer holidays in 1909. Her salary was $350.00 per annum, which was increased to $400.00 on January 1st, 1912. She taught this school till June 30th, 1914, and was re-engaged as assistant teacher of the Garden River (R.C.) School, beginning duties April 1st, 1915, at a salary of $400.00 per annum. This was increased to $450.00 on July 1st, 1916, and further increased to $500.00 on July 1st, 1917, and further increased to $550.00, her present salary, on January 1st, 1920. Besides salary she has also received bonus at the rate of $150.00 per annum during the past three years. This covers a period of thirteen years.

The Department has, in the past, granted a gratuity on retirement in several cases, as follows:

In 1909, Mrs. C. A. Vollick, who had taught the No. 3 School on the Oneida Reserve for a period of 17 years and who resigned on account of failing health, was granted a gratuity of $100.00, in recognition of her long and faithful service. The salary allowed her at that time was at the rate of $300.00 per annum.

A gratuity
A gratuity was granted Miss Annie Kehoe, teacher of the Goulais Bay Indian Day School in June, 1915. Miss Kehoe was in the service of the Department for eight years. She contracted tuberculosis from her work among the Indians. In addition to teaching, she acted as field matron and visited and attended the sick on the two reserves on which she had taught. The Department allowed her a gratuity equal to one-quarter of her yearly salary, or total of $125.00.

L. F. Hardyman, teacher of the Anglican School on the Garden River Reserve, after completing 30 years of service as a teacher in Indian schools, was granted a gratuity equal to six months' salary (March 31, 1919). The amount paid him was $300.00.

In November, last, Mr. John R. Lickers, teacher of the No. 5 School on the Six Nations Reserve, retired after 35 years' service as a teacher in Indian schools. He was allowed a gratuity of six months' salary, which amounted to $350.00.

Mr. Agent McNabb states that Miss McDermott has been a faithful, efficient, painstaking teacher, always at her post, never finding fault with her work or surroundings, but cheerful and kind and beloved by her pupils and recommends that the Department grant her some assistance for the few remaining years of her life.

I would draw your attention to the case of Miss Kehoe, mentioned above, who was granted a gratuity on retirement on account of tuberculosis, which she claimed she contracted on account of her association with the Indians.

I would recommend, in view of the Miss McDermott's faithful service and the circumstances under which she is compelled to resign and also to the fact that it is impossible for teachers to save any money from the salaries paid them, that the Department allow her a gratuity on her retirement equal to at least one quarter's salary, namely, $137.50. This could be paid from the appropriation for Indian Education, as was done in the cases mentioned above.

I have received a letter from Miss Angela Toner the Teacher at the Goulais Bay school asking to be transferred to the Garden River School in her Sister's place and let her Sister take the Goulais Bay School. I do not approve of changing from one school to another although I do believe that Miss Angela is a better Teacher than her Sister, I cannot say that I am very favorably impressed with either of them. I am satisfied that the best Teacher in my Agency is where there are the least number of Pupils, I mean Miss Rose Chaput at Batchewana. I would be very willing to let Miss Toner at Garden exchange with Miss Chaput after the summer Holidays. If Miss Daly had remained here until this time we would have had a number of children in the High School, but now I cannot see that any of them are any farther along in their studies than when she left, as far as I can see I do think that Miss Chaput would do better work at Garden River than any one since Miss Daly left. Miss Cahill was good and was well liked by the Pupils and Parents but she was only teaching the Junior Classes. I tried to get her to come back but she would not for even a raise of pay, she gave me her reason but I do not want to interfere with the Teachers as long as the Inspector is satisfied. At the same time I do not think it would be wise to make the change asked for, of course I will leave that for Mr Ferrier to decide, I am satisfied to live up to what he says.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo, regarding the services being performed by Miss Mildred Toner, Senior Teacher of the Garden River R. C. Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that, in view of the reports of the Separate School Inspector, the Travelling Nurse and yourself concerning the work in the classroom, the condition of the school room and the poor attendance, it has been decided that it would be in the interests of the work to make a change of senior teacher for the next school year. Miss Ada Bush, the present junior teacher, may remain for the next school year. You should also ascertain from her whether she will be prepared to return after the summer holidays and inform the Department accordingly.

Regarding the appointment of a teacher at Batchawana to succeed Miss Chaput, I beg to say that we will approve of the appointment of Miss Beila Pelletier who formerly taught this school. The salary allowed her will be the same as is now paid Miss Chaput. All the above salaries will be supplemented by any bonus provided by law.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your night letter of the first, your telegram of the 2nd and your letter of the first instant—all with reference to the proposed building activity in connection with the Garden River R. C. Indian Day School. I have to confirm official day letter of today's date, as follows:

"Reference Garden River Roman Catholic Day School.

It is considered false economy to move present school building and to erect separate teacher's residence. Arrangements will be made to prepare plans and let contract for combined school and residence early next spring. Full explanation in today's letter."

I have to inform you that the proposed building activity in the case of this school has been given serious consideration, and, in view of your recommendation, it has been decided that lot 135, of the new survey of the reserve, would be the most central site for the Roman Catholic pupils. As you were informed in the official telegram, it is not considered wise to move a 26-year-old building, at considerable cost, to a site on the main road. The Superintendent of Indian Education and the Separate School Inspector both report that the present school is not attractive from any standpoint. A new teacher's residence has to be erected in any case, and it is considered in the best interests of economy to arrange for a combined school and teacher's residence. Such a building would contain two classrooms on the ground floor with cloak-rooms for children. The teacher's living rooms would be upstairs and might consist of a combined kitchen and dining-room, two bedrooms with clothes closets, etc. A proper basement should be provided with furnace and perhaps a dry chemical closet for winter's use. The funds necessary, over and above the $8,000 which will be taken from the Garden River and Batchewana Capital Accounts, will be provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education.

The plans for such a building should be prepared by the Department and the contract awarded. I regret that this arrangement does not provide adequate residence facilities for the two teachers at the Garden River Indian Day School for the coming winter, and the Department will give favourable consideration to any recommendation you make with a view to ameliorating conditions for them.

You should make arrangements with the members of the Band to release lot 135 for school purposes. The resolution in this connection should be forwarded to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
A. D. McNabb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
SAULT STE. MARIE, ONT.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, enclosing a petition from the members of the Garden River and Batchawana Bands requesting that Miss Rose Chaput be retained as teacher at the Garden River R. C. Indian Day School.

In reply I have to refer you to official letter of the 17th ultimo, in which you were informed that the Department had made arrangements with the Nardene Sisters at Spanish, Ont., for the future teaching services at this school. Miss Chaput was informed on the same date of these arrangements and also that her services would not be required at the Garden River School after the end of the school year which has recently closed. She was also informed that, if she is desirous of continuing in Indian school work, if she would write the Department, her application would receive favourable consideration. I may say that we have already placed Miss Bush in a suitable school, but no word has been received from Miss Chaput as to whether she desires another school or not.

A number of our day schools are being conducted by the Nardene Sisters, who are giving excellent satisfaction, and the Department considered, when they made the offer to take over the Garden River R. C. School, that it would be in the best interests of the work to have them do so. The Nardene Sisters are a teaching Order and besides, these workers take an active interest in the welfare of the Indians - not only in the work they perform as teachers, but also among the older Indian women on the Reserve. We have already received the nomination of the two teachers who are taking charge of this school, and it is hoped to inform you in the near future of their names, salary, etc.

You should inform the Indians who signed the petition forwarded by you of the arrangements made for the future carrying on of the teaching activity at this school. The Department regrets that it is unable to comply with their request to continue the services of Miss Chaput.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I have been appointed to take charge of the Junior Class at Garden River, over one year ago. You advised me to carry out the policy which I thought best for the good of the children and the school. I want to thank you for that advice and I followed it very closely and I can say that progress was made. I have stuck strictly to the interest of my class in order to avoid friction and even at that I have to take a lot of abuse and interference which really does not affect my teaching but makes life pretty miserable.

Last year I put on a concert with the Junior Class only. The class did very well and was highly appreciated by Mr. Greening, the School Inspector and Mr. J.J. Young, who were present for the concert. This year I want to put on a similar concert by the Juniors.
to avoid any friction, interference or misunderstanding I would like a note from you authorizing me to do so as interference has already begun in this matter.

I like Garden River very much and there is a great deal of work to be done with the children.

There are thirty-five children in my class ranging from seven to ten years. There are thirteen boys who can serve mass and say the Latin prayers by heart. Six of my last year boys have passed into the Senior Room having nineteen altar boys in all. This was one of the greatest accomplishments. The Cubs have been organized and are progressing nicely. Their initiation will take place early in the New Year.

Father Dwyer has built a large hall and it is at the disposal of the children. This hall is the basement of the new church and Mass will be said there till the upper structure is completed. Father also bought the school ground which is joined to the school yard. It allows the children to play in it but the school yard is rather small. Father is expecting a Resident priest but he has not arrived yet. I hope that he will.
arrive soon and lighten Father's responsibilities.

The coal stores were a problem but Father Davis showed us how to clear them and they have been wonderful.

I expect that you will give my request prompt attention as the situation is not very bright.

I thank you for all favours and I will strive to go about with my duties correctly and efficiently.

Sincerely yours,

Mary Morris.

I considered this a most unusual request as a matter of this kind should be settled by the Principal. With this in mind, I wrote Miss Morris and sent a copy to Miss Goody (see copy attached). Miss Morris has replied and from this letter, it is more or less evident that the Principal and herself are not on very good terms.

I know you visit the Garden River Reserve regularly and while I dislike troubling you, I thought you might be aware of the situation and would let me know exactly what the trouble is. It is understood that anything you write will be treated confidentially.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Philan:

I have been awaiting a reply regarding the Junior Class Room at Garden River for the term 1947-48, and since no word has come I have drawn two conclusions:

General Inspection Report -

These classrooms are heated with standard heaters. They are well lighted from six windows. Both classrooms have recently been painted in an attractive light green shade with white trim.

Ottawa, October 2nd, 1929.

Sir,-

Dear Sir,

I received salary cheque for September quarter and I thank you. Please allow me to ask the Department to kindly forward my cheques directly to me in the future, as was always done in all the other schools where I taught.

I have a reason for asking this favor and it is this: the cheques were brought to the school here in an unsealed envelope by one of the men of the reserve, and I have no desire that my cheques pass through their hands, if it possibly can be avoided.

Thanking you for all past favors, I am

Respectfully yours,
[Signature]

Ottawa, July 22nd, 1930.

Sir:

I have to inform you of the arrangements made for a change in the teaching staff at the Garden River R. C. Indian Day School for the next school year. Miss S. Fox, the junior teacher, is retiring from the work and will be succeeded by Miss M. Hickey, who is an experienced teacher. Miss Hickey will be allowed salary at the same rate as was paid Miss Fox, viz., $50 per teaching month. Miss O. O'Driscoll, the senior teacher, will return. Both she and Miss Hickey will reopen the school on September 2nd, next. I have to request that you will give both these teachers any assistance you can in their work.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

G. H. Sims, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Your letter of 7th stated that my salary would be $35.00 a month. For the past two months my cheque has been $79.05. I thought it was well to let you know. There might have been a mistake in making out the cheques.

Ottawa,
March 17, 1941.

Dear Miss Walsh:

With reference to your letter of the 11th instant present regulations provide that in the case of teachers appointed since September 1, 1939, a 5% deduction will be made from their salary. In your case this amounts to $4.25 a teaching month. This amount is refundable and when you discontinue teaching in an Indian day school you may apply for same and it will be returned to you plus interest.

All employees are also subject to a 3% deduction for National Defence tax. This amounts to $1.70. The two deductions total $5.95 and consequently the amount of $79.05 which was forwarded to you is correct.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Miss Margaret Walsh,
Teacher,

Dear Sir,

Indian agent Van. Abbot communicated to you my request for pecuniary assistance that enable me to build a new school-house, and for an augmentation in the salary in view of having two teachers in the spring and in the fall when the number of children is very large.

The reply has been that 500 dollars might be granted provided the band consent. It seems most probable that it would not consent, so except perhaps if that money were taken from their consolidated fund.

Now I find in the law ruling Indians affairs a means to build this school without asking from the people a cent more than what is due. (Ch. 43, 16975.) For a read as follows: "... the teacher 'always' shall be of the same denomination as the majority of the band, and... the Protestant or Catholic minority may likewise have a separate school..." Consequently in any Indian reserve, the principal school must be always of the same denomination as the majority of the band, and again consequently the principal salary must be paid to the teacher belonging to the same denomination.

Now the Catholics are in the Garden River band, and have been for years, if not always, in great majority. The only school supported by that band (or the principal one, if there must be two) ought to have been theirs, and must become now theirs if the law is the law.

The Garden River band pays (if my informations are right) 300 dollars to the first school, and probably nothing to our Catholic teacher who is paid.
By the Bahnawang band.

The law shall be observed if the 500 dollars are given to us. Being sure of that sum yearly, I will have a second teacher where it will be necessary, and borrow money to build the new school large enough to seat as many children as might come from the two bands. And when the school-house will be all set instead of 600 dollars yearly (300 from the Garden River and 300 from the Bahnawang) I might be able to do with 200, provided the 200 gift be applied to another teacher at Goulais Bay. So the Indians will not have to give rent as they do already; and the law will be obeyed.

I hope, Sir, that you will be able to give me a prompt answer because I must start the work as soon as possible.

I remain, dear Sir,

Your servant in X,

Then at your school, or that accommodation could be provided for all the children on the Reserve in your school when rebuilt. TO HIS EXCELLENCY
THE GOVERNOR GENERAL
IN COUNCIL.

The undersigned begs to report that the building in which the Roman Catholic School on the Garden River Reserve is conducted affords inadequate accommodation, and as the building was not originally intended for a school it has proved to be quite unsuited for the purpose.

The authorities of the Roman Catholic Church have decided to provide a new building, but have asked that assistance be given, as has been done in similar cases, from the funds of the Batchewana and Garden River Bands of Indians, in whose interest the school is conducted. Plans of the proposed building have been submitted and approved by the Department of Indian Affairs. The estimated cost of erecting and equipping the building is $1900. The undersigned considers that $1000 of the funds of the Indians interested would be well spent in helping in the erection of the proposed building, as it will be of permanent and great interest to these Bands to have a well-appointed school.

The
The undersigned would therefore respectfully recommend that authority be given, under Section 70 of the Indian Act, as enacted by Section 2, Chapter 35, 58,59 Victoria, for contributing towards the erection and equipment of the aforesaid school building the sum of $333.34 from the capital of the Batchewana Band, which amounts to $14,408.46, and $666.66 from the capital of the Garden River Band, which amounts to $72,404.32; these contributions being proportionate to the number of children of these Bands attending the school.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your welcome letter of Oct. 3rd, 1895, I beg to say that the contract for the school-house has been signed yesterday night, and that the contractor is satisfied to receive his payment by advances made to him as the work progresses or estimates certified to by Mr. William Van Abbé.

As for the specifications, I must say that one or two modifications have been made, adding to the solidity of the building (four feet of stone foundation instead of three under the ground); but improving some of the inside good looking (instead of having walls and ceiling oil-finished and varnished, we will have it painted). These modifications have been proposed by one of the contractors about ten days ago, to allow him the possibility to reduce his tender from $1700 to $1500. Having made the same propositions to the man that offered the lowest bid, he agreed to erect this building for a sum of $1380 dollars.

To the Department contributing one thousand towards the building, the Mission, beside the ground on which the school will be and the play-yard, gives $280. And as I intended to spend $500, I will have the desks and seats made at our own expenses.

I will send today to Mr. Van Abbé a copy of the specifications.

I remain, Dear Sir,

Your servant in X,

J. O. Ortho.

Figure 1.

Figure 1 represents the seat arm showing "socket" which fits over the "ball" on Figure 2 (which represents upright seat arm). This socket is called a "ball and socket," or, as it is termed by some, a "trunnion joint" hinge. When the seat arm (Figure 1) is fastened over the standard (Figure 2), the entire weight rests upon the seat arm socket joint and whatever on the bolt, it being merely used to clamp the seat arm and standard together. On close inspection you will observe two iron lugs which are the stops when the seat is folded down or up.

Figure 3 illustrates reverse side of seat arm showingitudinal grooves in which the steel bicycle balls run. Figure 4 is a cap which fits over grooves in Figure 3. You will observe that cap 4 is grooved to correspond with Figure 3, and when they are fastened together they form a trunnion joint in the middle than at either end, through which the balls roll as seat is moved up or down. Figure 5 represents the reverse side of seat. Note that the face of Figure 5 is "dished", or concave in shape. When hinge is put together a cap is placed over the ball in Figure 6 fits over the dish in Figure 5. The different parts are then bolted together with bolts and washers. The tall piece in caps 4 and 5 passes through hole in standard (2) maintaining both cap and standard in one stationary position, the seat arm moving between them.
The Little Balls Do the Work.

The Steel Bicycle Balls Inside the Hinge of the "Ball Bearing" Increase the Life of the Hinge Many Years and Make It Absolutely and Permanently Noiseless.

Figure 7 shows seat arm (Figure 3) is moved up or down the hinge groove in any direction. This groove, as before stated, is inclined and as the balls approach their stopping place this narrowing space in groove, or rather tube, forces out or expands the cap Figure 4, which is made possible by the reverse side of cap being dish shaped with a flat steel washer over it, which sticks into the dish as the pressure of the ball forces the cap out. When pressure is released, the seat the weight of cap part does not rest on balls, but on the ball and socket joint before described, and the stops or lugs described in Figure 6. The purpose of the balls and the steel washer is merely to act as a brake and arrest the force of the stop when seat is folded or opened. There is no weight or undue pressure on them, but the weight rests entirely on the ball and socket joint and stops.

Figure 7 shows seat folded down with cap (Figure 4) made transparent so as to show position and workings of balls. C, C, C represent inclined grooves in which balls run. D, D, D, the stops or ends of grooves.

Figure 8 shows seat folded up with position of balls consequently reversed.

Figure 9 shows a sectional view of the complete hinge put together. The seat is folded down and you are supposed to be directly in front on a level with the hinge looking into it. B represents desk standard. F represents seat arm. D represents "ball" or stumps. G represents "socket" on arm. C represents lugs or stops on standard and arm. F, F, F, represent the steel bicycle balls rolling around in groove or tube. H represents soldered joint in tube. I represents the tail piece that passes into hole in standard, keeping the cap in stationary position. J represents steel washer before described in Figure 6. As the seat is folded down, the balls have forced the cap out slightly and the steel spring washer, as you will observe, is sprung into the dish of cap. J represents nut on bolt. A represents head of bolt which passes entirely through seat hinge, clamping the whole together and forming the only common sense, permanently noiseless hinge ever placed on a school desk.
Fastening of Wood and Iron.

The accompanying cut plainly shows our exclusive method of fastening wood work to iron. B represents upright standard. A represents lug which slips into mortise D in back of wood work. There is a main casting, C, on the opposite side from lug A, extending the whole length of back. When the wood is placed over the iron lug A, fitting into mortise D, the back is driven downward and the lug A acts as a wedge, forcing the flange of standard firmly into the recessed groove C in wood work, thus producing continuous fastening the whole length of the wood. The wood work of seat and top of desk is fastened to the iron in a similar manner. This is the only common sense method of putting up school desks. We believe we are the ones who invented it and who have a monopoly of its use. E represents wood work showing dovetailed groove. When lug A is placed in mortise D and driven down, the lug A wedges the flange before described firmly, forming a permanently secure fastening.

Note the perfect tongued and grooved glued joints; we make our tongues and grooves very large in size and of a peculiar shape which gives an extraordinary amount of glue spread, thereby making the most perfect joint possible. Our method of jointing has stood the test of years, and no other desk made can compare with it in this particular.

Garden River, Oct. 22, 1899

To the Secretary Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

In order to place the new desks which have been purchased for the R.C. School at Garden River it will be necessary to remove a chimney which is placed just in the middle of one of the rooms. Some alterations have been made in the school; this chimney has always been in the way very much, but as the long desks were set in two rows only, they could go on each side of the chimney, but the new desks will have to be fixed in three rows so I would like to be authorized to remove that chimney. There are two chimneys in the school. But it is good to remember that the school was built for one teacher only with the intention of giving lodging to the teacher, and one of these chimneys would have been used in that case for the teacher's apartment. But since the new school was built, the number of pupils has increased considerably so that it was found necessary to make two rooms and to remove the partition where is the chimney mentioned, in order to enlarge one room. I do not intend to remove the chimney altogether, but have the top of it and set it on the rafters so that it will not spoil the appearance of the school, and might be used in case of necessity.

For the present I will bring the two stove pipes in the same chimney. I think that I can have this job made for $4 or $5 dollars and for sure it will cost around $7 dollars - an immediate answer is kindly solicited for we expect the new desks from day to day.

Yours respectfully,
Rev. H. Schumacher, Principal Teacher,
Garden River, Oct. 22, 1899.

Building in good repair, but needs painting.
Extract from report of Rev. V. Renaud, S.J., teacher of the Garden River (R.C.) School, for the year ending December 31, 1911.

To improve the attendance it would be necessary to hire a man with a team from December to April to collect the children. I think that somebody here would do the work for 50¢ a trip or $1.00 a day. As for the parents who live near the school and keep their children at home I think a little fine should be imposed upon them.
Ottawa, January 29, 1912.

Sir,

Rev. Father Renaud, who is in charge of the Roman Catholic School on the Garden River Reserve, suggests that arrangements should be made to have some of the children conveyed to and from the school during the winter months.

I have to ask you to be good enough to report on the distance these children reside from the school and what numbers, if any, there are residing at such distances that it is not possible for them to walk.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Murdoch MacLennan, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
Ottawa, January 31, 1912.

Sir,

It has been reported to the Department that the Garden River (R.C.) School is in need of painting. I have to ask you to be good enough to report as to the probable cost and the best means of having this work done. I may say that on a previous occasion when painting had to be done on this reserve the Department supplied the material and the Indians did the labour and this might be the best method to follow in this particular case, if it is decided to take action.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Murdoch MacLennan, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 153328/5 January 27th, in which you request me to report upon the matter in question. I have given the matter considerable thought during the winter months, and find that the children who reside at a distance that would be considered too far to walk, are those now living on the part called "French Bay," and are largely, if not altogether, members of the Bathurst Band. The school has been held about 2/3 of the time at this school, and some of them work or live from 2½ to 3 miles away, and as the roads are now in good order and should be better for the balance of the winter, I would think that the expenses of a conveyance would be too large. It will be necessary further details concerning the fact that the Bathurst Band are anxious to have their rights on the Gordon River more definitely defined, and I am now doing what I can to do so in that connection.

J D McLean, Esq.,
Acting Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Garden River, March 25-1912

Mr. Murdoch McLenan
Sault Ste Marie

Dear Sir,

At last, I saw John Boyer yesterday, and spoke to him about the painting of the schoolhouse.

If the Department supplies the paint, John will charge $2.50 a day, and it will take him about 16 days to give two coats. Now, if you like better to give him the job, he will supply the paint and do the whole work for $70.00. By the "whole work" I mean the outside wall only. I think it is cheap enough, and neither you nor I would do the same work for that price.

The size of the main building is 22 x 46 ft., the wall being 16 ft. high. Besides, there is the equivalent of a building of 14 x 22 ft., with a 8 ft. high wall.

With these dimensions, one can find out how much paint it would require.

Yours truly,

W. Renaud S.J.
Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge with your letter No. 15328/15 January 31st to inquire enclosed from Mr. R. O. Rumant, Principal of the R.C. School on the Sarnia River Reserve, in which he submits an offer of John Boyce, a member of the Band, to do the job of painting the outside of the school for $70.

I asked Mr. Rumant, if the Indians of the Band would be able to do the work required by the Department, and he stated that he did not think there was many of the Band that could do the work.

Considering the fact that the Sarnia River Band is acting for the painting of the Council Chamber on the Reserve, I would think that our competent painter could do the work.

If it is desired to have the important done to better advantage, I find that it will require about 20 gallons of paint to give two coats inside and outside of the R.C. School, which will cost about $25 per gallon at the current market price.

J. D. McLean Esq.,
Acting Deputy and Secretary,

Specifications for painting the exterior of the Garden River (R.C.) School-house, Garden River Reserve.

1. **Painting.** Paint all exposed exterior wood and iron work two good coats of lead and oil, tinted as directed by the Agent in charge.

2. **Cleaning Off.** Providing there is any loose or dead paint adhering to the wood-work, this to be carefully scraped and sandpapered from the wood-work, and any live knots or pitch showing on the surface all to be carefully covered with best shellac.

3. **Material.** The lead to be used to be best Canadian white Lead (ground in oil), pure boiled linseed oil and pure spirits of turpentine as dryer.

4. The first coat to have sufficient oil to thoroughly penetrate the wood and bind the lead and pigment thereto; and when dry to be finished with a heavy flowing coat of lead and oil of tint as required.

5. All work to be done in a good and womanlike manner and to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent.
Ottawa, April 4, 1912.

Dear Sir,

Regarding your letter, No. 444,479, dated 19th May 1914, re, the erection of a fence around the Roman Catholic cemetery at Garden River, I am anxious to learn whether and when the Department intend granting the same. We have been waiting now quite a while for it, the matter is urgent.

Another point I beg to bring to the notice of the Department, viz., the necessity of some repairs about the Roman Catholic Schoolhouse, among others, the two porches, a covering over the bell on the roof, etc. I mentioned this to Mr. Indian Agent Mr. Webb, lately. He said he knew about it and would look after it. Still, I thought that I should say a word about this matter to the Department, as school is to open at the end of this month.

Hoping that the Department will take these matters into its kind consideration,

I am, dear Sir,
Yours truly,
Jos. Specht, S.J.

Sir,-

I have to draw attention to the fact that on the 29th December you sent to the Department an account of $6.25 in favour of Miss Luise Lasage for service as caretaker of the Roman Catholic School at Garden River Reserve during December quarter last. The voucher in question was paid by cheque No. 3441 which went forward on the 14th of January. In view of this fact you should explain why you sent to the Department on the 30th March a voucher in favour of Antoine Boyer, rendered at $10.00, for service as caretaker of the above mentioned school from the 5th December to the 29th February. The Department is paying Boyer $5.00 by cheque No. 4519, which is going forward for service as caretaker of the school during January. Two caretakers will not be employed at the same time for the school and consequently payment will not be made to Boyer for service rendered during December. You should see that a caretaker is appointed at a yearly salary to do the work in question at that school.

I may say that it is considered that $25.00 a year should be ample remuneration. This is the amount allowed for the services of the kind at other schools. The appointment is only left in your hands, and the Department relies upon you to see that the work is entrusted to a responsible person. You should report without delay as to the action you have taken.

I may add that the allowance of $5.00 a month authorised by official letter of the 7th December last for A. D. McHagg Esq.,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th instant No 153328-5 in reference to the out buildings at the Garden River R. C. School and in reply would say that it is my intention to use all the old timber that can possibly be used to advantage. I consider that there are about legs enough to build the new shed etc we may require some few pieces of lumber for the roof, I would recommend having the Roof Shingled.

The estimate of $100.00 is just a rough estimate by myself and one of the Indians before we go on with the work I will try and get an estimate from a practical mechanic.

Awaiting your further instructions,

I have the honor to be Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, March 29, 1920

Sir,

Inspector Bennett, who recently visited the Garden River Roman Catholic Indian Day School, reports as follows: "Porch floor and door need repairs. Stove in teacher's residence needs repairs, teacher's residence needs wood."

Kindly have the necessary repairs made as soon as possible, and you may also purchase sufficient wood to last until the warm weather comes. In making the purchase of the wood or of any material required for the above repairs you will be guided by the requirements of the War Purchasing Commission.

The inspector also states that the attendance is very unsatisfactory. Possibly this has to some extent been due to the weather but there is no reason why the attendance at present should not be improved and the Department will expect you to take steps to increase the attendance at this school.

Your obedient servant

J. D. McLEAN

Sardin River Indian Day School:

1. Roof of school leaks a little in one place. There are no ladders to enable one to fix it.

OTTAWA, May 4th, 1922.

Sir,

Mr. J. M. Bennett, the Separate School Inspector, reports regarding the Garden River Indian Day School as follows:

1. Roof of school leaks a little in one place. There are no ladders to enable one to fix it.

2. Teachers report that the building is terribly cold in winter, due to lack of putty on windows, floor boards heaved up, roof leaking almost all around edges of eaves - painting urgent - new roof needed. In fact, a new house should be built as almost as much would be spent on repairs.

3. Teachers' residence is such that in case of fire it would be so inflammable that the church and nearby buildings would be burnt.

4. Teachers, I understand, will have to vacate the residence in June, as it is in such condition that it is no fit habitation.

The outstanding remark is this: - Somebody will have to provide a new teacher's residence for September. Can something be done immediately?

Regarding this report, I have to request that you will arrange to have the roof of the school building repaired, and you should furnish a report and estimate of the cost of the work that would be required to place the school building in good repair for next winter.

Regarding the teachers' residence, I have also to request that you will furnish a report as to the work that would be required to place this building in good repair, and make it comfortable for the teachers' use.

This information should be received as soon as possible in order that, if it is decided to undertake any repairs, the work could be carried on and completed during the coming summer holidays. In making your report as to the desirability of a new teachers' residence, you will take into consideration the remarks of the Inspector mentioned above, and state whether, in your opinion, the present building could not be repaired without any large expenditure.

We will expect an early reply giving full information regarding the school and teachers' residence, and the cost of having any repairs considered necessary carried out.

Your obedient servant,

D. McNabb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
Ont.

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th instant No 13-3-5 and have to say.

1st The roof of the School room does leak in one place, but it does not need a new Roof.

There are no ladders at this school, and we need one very much.

2nd Those paragraphs of your letter must refer to the Teachers dwelling house, I quite agree with all that is said in reference to this building, IT CANNOT BE REPAIRED. It would cost more to repair this building than it would take to build a nice cottage with 2 bedrooms, a dining Room Parlor and small Kitchen, a one Storey house.

3rd We need a Woodshed at this School and also to have the Kiss Closets removed and wood shed built where the closets now stand. We are losing wood every year and have no way of checking the loss as it is only an open shed.

The cost of repairing the School roof would not cost over $5,00 for Shingles and Labor. I cannot estimate the cost of repairs to the Teachers dwelling as it is not worth spending any money on it, it is a menace to the Church and other buildings, all frame and as dry as tinder.

Should you decide to build a Teachers cottage and a woodshed I will get you prices as soon as I get plans of the buildings.

Awaiting your further instructions,

I have the honor to be Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

Ottawa, May 23, 1922.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 18th instant, with reference to the repairs required to the school and teacher's residence at the Garden River R. C. Indian Day School.

1. In connection with the repairs needed to the roof to prevent leakage, I beg to say that you should arrange to have this work done as soon as possible. It is noted that you estimate the cost to be about $5.00.

2. You may arrange to have a ladder made for this school, or, if you consider it cheaper, you may purchase one of the length needed.

3. Regarding the teacher's residence, I beg to say that we will have no funds this year to erect a new residence for the teachers at this school. If a few minor repairs could be carried out in order to make the building as comfortable as possible for another year, I will be pleased if you will state the nature of the work that would be needed. Only such repairs should be undertaken as are necessary to enable the teachers to reside there with a fair degree of comfort for another winter.

4. Regarding a wood shed and the removal of the closets, I will be pleased if you will furnish an estimate of the cost of building a wood shed large enough to provide storage for the fuel used, as well as a small compartment for other storage purposes. A small building with a sloping roof and rough boarded walls should serve the purpose. The doors should have proper padlocks or other means of being securely fastened. You will have an idea of the size that will be required to meet the demands.

I will be pleased if you will state approximately the amount that will be necessary to erect this wood shed and have the closets removed and placed in good condition on another site. I may say that we have no plans for a wood shed. Kindly furnish this estimate, also that for the minor repairs to the teacher's residence, as soon as possible so that, if it is decided to authorize the work, it can be done during the summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir:—

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant, furnishing an estimate of the cost of building a wood shed, removing the closets and repairing the roof at the Garden River Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange to have this work done, and the cost should not exceed the estimate submitted by you, viz.: $120 to have a wood shed erected, large enough to provide storage for the fuel used as well as containing a small compartment for other storage purposes. The teachers have to burn green wood all winter, therefore, they consume more kindling and it is very hard to get the school heated. Ottawa, March 28th, 1923.

Sir:

The senior teacher of the Garden River R.C. Indian Day School, in her annual report for the present fiscal year states that it has been very hard to get the school rooms heated owing to the fact that green wood has been used all winter. She recommends that ladders that would lead to the chimney of the school should be supplied. She also states that it is impossible to get any one to clean the pipes of the school rooms or house because they have not been paid for the last work they did, and also that it is difficult to get any other necessary work done.

Regarding the wood, you should arrange to have the supply required for next winter delivered at the school, where it could be stored and dried, and would be ready for next winter's use. This matter should receive your attention, and a request should be made early in the summer for the necessary authority to purchase the quantity required.

You should state whether you consider that ladders are necessary, and if so, the cost of supplying the same.

If there are any amounts due for work performed in connection with this school, you should furnish properly certified vouchers, and, if satisfactory, payment will be made.

As it is difficult for the teachers to attend to the care-taking, I would be pleased to have your views as to whether you consider it would be advisable to appoint a janitor to do the care-taking and other necessary work around the school, and, if so, the amount of salary you would suggest be allowed for this service.

Your attention to the above matters will oblige,

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 25th ultimo No. 13-3-5 in reference to the heating of the Roman Catholic School, I beg to say that heretofore we have had no complaints about the heating of this school. We have used more dry wood during this time Miss Toner has been teacher than we have in the last two years. She does not seem to want to use green wood, and it is impossible for me to get her dry wood now.

In regard to the clogging of the pipes in the school room, I had Mike Larose clean the pipes and put on the storm windows and Miss Toner neglected to send his bill. This is the reason that he has not been paid.
