The following is a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Treasury Board, held on the 18th October, 1923, approved by His Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the 19th October, 1923.

Indian Affairs -

The Board had under consideration a memorandum from the Honourable the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs reporting that the residence in use by the teachers of the Indian Day School used by the Roman Catholic portion of the Garden River and Batchawana Indians and situated on the Garden River Indian reserve, in the district of Algoma in the province of Ontario, is inadequate and so dilapidated as to be beyond repair, and it is necessary to replace the same at a cost estimated at $2,000.00 for a suitable four-room cottage to accommodate the two teachers employed; that a capital at the credit of the Garden River and Batchawana bands amounts respectively to $97,822.86 and $67,117.51, and it is proposed to meet the cost of the new building from their funds in proportion to the number of children attending the school from the two bands, namely, $1,500.00 from the Garden River band and $500.00 from the Batchawana band.

The Superintendent General recommends that under Section 89 of the Indian Act, authority be given for the above mentioned expenditures of $1,500.00 and $500.00 being made from the Garden River and Batchawana capital accounts, respectively, on the construction of the teachers' residence referred to.

The Board concur in the above recommendation and submit the same for favourable consideration.

Clerk of the Privy Council.

The Honourable

The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa, Nov. 5, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your night letter of the first, your telegram of the 2nd and your letter of the first instant - all with reference to the proposed building activity in connection with the Garden River R. C. Indian Day School. I have to confirm official day letter of today's date, as follows:

"Reference Garden River Roman Catholic Day School.
It is considered false economy to move present school building and to erect separate teacher's residence. Arrangements will be made to prepare plans and let contract for combined school and residence early next spring. Full explanation in today's letter."

I have to inform you that the proposed building activity in the case of this school has been given serious consideration, and, in view of your recommendation, it has been decided that lot 185, of the new survey of the reserve, would be the most central site for the Roman Catholic pupils. As you were informed in the official telegram, it is not considered wise to move a 26-year-old building, at considerable cost, to a site on the main road. The Superintendent of Indian Education and the Separate School Inspector both report that the present school is not attractive from any standpoint. A new teacher's residence has to be erected in any case, and it is considered in the best interests of economy to arrange for a combined school and teacher's residence. Such a building would consist of two classrooms on the ground floor with cloakrooms for children. The teacher's residence would be upstairs and might consist of a combined kitchen and dining-room, two bedrooms with clothes closets, etc. A proper basement should be provided, with furnace and perhaps a dry chemical closet for winter's use. The funds necessary, over and above the $2,000 which will be taken from the Garden River and Batchawana Capital Accounts, will be provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education.

The plans for such a building should be prepared by the Department and the contract awarded. Memorandum:

Mr. Orr,

A two-roomed school and teachers' residence combined is required for the Garden River R. C. cause. Mr. Indian Agent McNabb has been requested to have the members of the Band release Lot 165 of the new survey of the Reserve for a site.

The building should provide two classrooms, which will accommodate a total of 60 pupils. The junior room with the smaller desks should accommodate 35 pupils and the senior room, 25. You will remember that we discussed the best type of building and agreed on the classrooms with children's cloakroom on the ground floor. The teachers' residence could be on the second floor and might consist of a combined kitchen and dining room and two bed rooms with clothes closets, etc. A proper basement with furnace and perhaps a dry chemical closet for the teachers' use in winter is needed. $2,000 is available from the Garden River and Batchawana Bands' Capital Account and $3,000 will be provided in the Appropriation.

The need at this school is great and building operations should commence as soon as possible in the coming season.

A.D.

Between His Majesty King George the Fifth, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs of Canada (hereinafter called the Superintendent General);

and all other work and labour incidental to and necessary for the entire completion thereof, whether specified or shown in the drawings or specifications or not, by the day of A.D. 1924.

AND the Contractors for themselves their executors, administrators and assigns, further covenant and agree:

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. If this condition is violated the Superintendent General may cancel the contract and refuse to accept any work done thereunder.

2. That if the Contractors fail at any time to pay any account for any goods or materials supplied, or money advanced by anyone to the said Contractors for the purposes of this agreement, or to pay the account of any sub-contractor for any work or materials done or supplied for the said works to be constructed under this agreement, and such
account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractors to pay such account and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractors, and the Contractors covenant with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

3. That if the Contractors fail at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by them upon or in respect of the said works, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractors to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractors and the Contractors covenant with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

4. That pursuant to the Statute in that behalf, this Agreement is made subject to the express condition that no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this Agreement or any benefit to arise therefrom.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to outbuildings at the Garden River R. C. Indian Day School. Please have the contractors submit a price for the woodshed and for the three closets. The teacher's closet could be attached to the woodshed. EXTRACT FROM INSPECTOR'S REPORT ON THE GARDEN RIVER R. C.
MELANIE DAY SCHOOL, JANUARY 20, 1925.

New main building, 2 classrooms, 2 bedrooms, living room, kitchen and cellar appear well built.

A.- The contractor should not be fully paid until all is satisfactory. Rain entered through walls of one cloakroom and one classroom from the ceiling. It also entered over inside door of kitchen on the top and a few other places. The valley on the floor alongside the bedroom could not have been properly flashed with tin. This should be looked into before the plaster is destroyed.

B.- For some reason or other the beautiful white walls, here and there, even of the ceiling, have been splashed with varnish. (see below)

C.- The old teacher's desk and old school desks are still being used. They will do. However, they should be varnished. Summer time would be the best time so that a good job of them would be made.

D.- The doors should be weather stripped. They need it. Metal after all is best.

(2)- The two toilets and woodshed are up. The woodshed is certainly small. It is only 12 x 10. Rather small. Toilets should be screened as they are facing the road.

(3)- Playgrounds should be arranged for.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 2nd Instant No 13-3-5 in reference to the Garden River new R. C. School and in reply have to say, that I had an interview with Mr Brecken one of the Contractors and he informs me that the reason for the leakage in the building is that the ice forms on the eaves and backs up the water under the shingles and cause it to run down the walls he says if the ice was kept away from the eaves it would not leak.

He also claims that all valleys are flashed with 26 gauge iron the plan calls for 28 gauge.

The reason of the storm windows frosting is that the walls are damp from the lateness of the plastering although there has been fires kept going continually the walls have not got properly dried but after this season that complaint will be eliminated now the water runs down between the storm & inside windows and causes the dampness there.

Mr Brecken informs me that as soon as the snow is gone he will go down with me and rectify any defects in either the material or workmanship.

He also informs me that he will have the painter fix up the varnish stains on the walls.

In reference to varnishing the Teachers Desk and the old school seats I had in mind doing that in the summer vacation also put screens in front of the closets. Just at present it is utterly impossible to get a man at Garden to do any work as they are all away in the woods and it would cost too much to take a man from here. If the Inspector will give us time we will have all the work required done early in the spring.

I have the same to say about the small table I can get one made at Garden for one half what it would cost to buy one from the Furniture dealers. I have the order for their dishes on order with the T. E. Simpson Co Ltd. I can also get the Rock case made at the Garden for far less than I can buy it ready made. The washstand is also ordered and I understand on the way this was part of the Order given the Simpson Co for the furniture already delivered, they did not have the washstand in stock and ordered it to be sent to Garden River direct from Factory same as cupboard for dishes.

In reference to the desks I went by the sizes mentioned in your letter of Nov 29th No 13-3-5 giving the sizes for certain ages, I would suggest that we leave the desks as they are for the present.

On account of the heavy expenditure incurred in connection with the new School I am trying to keep the expenses as low as I can.

In reference to the playground when the spring opens up I will have a proposition to lay before the Council to have the present road passing in front of the School building closed and open another road about one hundred and fifty feet to the east of the School this will be for safety for the children. This will not cost much as it is only a few rods of a new road to build, however I will take this matter up later on.

Hoping this explanation is satisfactory.

June 10th, 1926.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Agent McNabb, Sault Ste. Marie, reported in December, last, that trouble was occasioned by the seepage of water into the cellar of the new Roman Catholic school building which was erected last summer, it being necessary to bail out the water on several occasions.

Mr. Orr states that the only way to effectively keep the basement dry would be to install on the outside at the bottom of the foundation wall all the way around the building a 4" field tile drain, same to be connected to the drain leaving the building.

Prices have been obtained by Mr. McNabb to have this work done. The lowest tender received by him for the excavating, supplying tile and relaying the drain to a ravine some 500' from the school was the sum of $493.40.

It will be necessary, in order to preserve the foundation of this building, that proper drainage facilities be provided. I shall be pleased to have your authority to instruct the Agent to arrange with the lowest tenderer to carry out this work. The Band Funds will not stand the expense, and it will be necessary to provide the same from our appropriation for Indian education.

Russell Ferrier
Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, June 16th, 1926.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, enclosing the quotations which you received for the excavating and putting in of a tile drain for the purpose of carrying away the water from the basement of the Garden River R. C. Indian Day School.

Marie, to excavate and lay a 4" tile drain at the proper depth all around the outside walls of the school at a satisfactory level to connect with a 4" tile drain to be carried into a ravine 500' from the school building. This drain should connect with basement catchbasin and should have ample fall to carry away all water from school building. Mr. Nicolson should complete this work to your entire satisfaction for the sum quoted by him of $493.40, including all labour and material. The Department will expect you to visit this school during the course of this work and see that it is being carried out satisfactorily. It is hoped that when this work has been finished there will be no further trouble as to the drainage at this school. The work should be undertaken and completed at the earliest possible date.

When the work has been completed, you should forward a voucher, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I am taking the liberty of writing you in connection with the R.C. School at Garden River, in looking it over recently I find several matters that need attention.

First. There is no proper place to get good water. Mr Bossineau and Mr Lessage two dependable men advise digging a well 10 or 12 ft deep. They are sure good water will be secured at that depth. Mr Bossineau has a well only 10 ft deep and gets splendid water. Digging and lining and proper covering would not cost over $30.00. I would recommend this as something must be done to get a better water supply.

Second. The roof of the School must be attended to, the plaster inside is already damaged from the water coming through. The ice forms on the lower part of the roof and the water backs up under the shingles. I would recommend galvanized iron be laid on the lower part of the roof extending from the eves up 4 or 5 ft around the entire building. This has been done on some of the large buildings in the City and has proved very satisfactory.

Third. The inside walls of the School are very dirty, and the damage done from the water has left them in bad shape. I would recommend all walls be sized and painted two coats, then heavy burlap put around the lower part of the rooms, as plaster is getting broken.

Fourth. The Teachers have asked for two ceiling registers to be put in, as their sleeping quarters are very cold in winter, also two screen doors and several screen windows are badly needed. If these repairs are made it will put the building in splendid shape.

I have the honor to be

Sir,
Your obedient servant.

J.D. McLean Esq.
Asst Deputy & Secretary,
Dept of Indian Affairs.

Ottawa, June 7, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, relative to the water supply and repairs required to the Garden River R. C. Indian Day School.

With reference to the water supply, I have to say the Department will approve of having a well dug at a suitable location near the school. It is noted you are of the opinion that good water can be secured at a depth of approximately 12 ft., and that the digging, lining and covering of the well would not cost over $250. You may arrange to have this well dug and a proper covering placed over same. No unnecessary expense should be incurred and, if possible, the cost should be kept down to the estimate mentioned by you.

Regarding the repairs to the roof, the renovating of the interior of the school and installing two ceiling registers, I shall be pleased if you will furnish an estimate of the cost of having galvanized iron laid on the lower part of the roof extending from the eaves up 4 or 5 ft. around the entire building; also the cost of having the interior walls sized and given two coats of paint and having burlap put around the lower part of the rooms. Please state, also, the cost of installing the two ceiling registers. In furnishing this estimate, you should state the cost of the materials and the labour, separately. When we have this information, consideration will be given to authorizing having the work done.

You may purchase and have installed two screen doors and several screens for the windows and forward a voucher, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

I shall be pleased to have your early reply, giving the information requested concerning the amount of the repairs mentioned above, so that, if it is decided to have this work done, it can be carried out during the coming summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR BENNETT,
dated September 30th, 1927, on his inspection of the Garden River R.C. Indian Day School.

Original on File 13-3-6.

"1. Cupboard needed for Jr. Room. Nothing there now.

2. New well is absolutely no good. The water coming from it smells and is tainted and cannot be used.

3. Walls of Jr. classroom need burlap as a protection from the children. That much of the wall is quite marked up."
Ottawa, October 8, 1927.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Garden River R. C. Indian Day School, states that a cupboard is needed for the junior classroom. It is thought that you might be able to arrange to have an inexpensive cupboard, with lock and key, built locally, which would serve the purpose. Please ascertain from a local carpenter the cost of building a suitable cupboard of an inexpensive type and inform the Department.

The Inspector further states that the new well is unsatisfactory and that the water obtained from it smells and is tainted and cannot be used. I shall be pleased to have a report from you regarding this matter. You should state what steps you would recommend be taken to remedy the conditions as mentioned by the Inspector.

The Inspector also states that the walls of the junior classroom should be burlap. He states the walls are marked up. Please state the approximate cost of having burlap placed around the walls of this classroom.

The Department will be pleased to have a report from you regarding the above matters at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

G. H. Sims, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
Ont.

Sault Ste Marie, Ont
October 12th 1927.

Sir,

I have your letter of October 8th inst No. 13-3-5 re water supply at R.G. School Garden River. In reply, I beg to say, that I would recommend that a pipe be driven the present well a sufficient depth to get away from the surface water. Of course there is the possibility that we may not be successful in getting water, but it is worth trying, the school certainly must be supplied with good water. Owing to the uncertainty of the proposition, I am unable to give an estimate as to the approximate cost, but I should say that the labour and material would not exceed $40.00.

Also re burlap for the walls of the Junior Class Room. I beg to submit what I consider a very reasonable figure for the job. The measurement around the wall is 33 yards, and the price put on, and one coat of paint is $1.10 per yd. I would strongly recommend that the two Class Rooms be done and also the two wash rooms, as the walls are very dirty. The entire measurement for all is 96 yds, and at $1.10 per yd complete would be $105.60.

Also a bookcase for the above school, I can have a very suitable one built, stained and varnished to match woodwork in school for the sum of $34.00.

I have the honor to be Sir,
Your obedient servant.

J.D. McLean Esq.
Asst Deputy & Secretary,
Dept of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa Ont.

Acting Agent.
Ottawa, October 13, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, relative to the well at the Garden River R. C. Indian Day School, also the burlapping of the walls and the providing of a bookcase.

With reference to the well, it is noted you recommend that a pipe be driven down the present well a sufficient depth to get away from the surface water and that you consider this would be the best arrangement to make. If you are satisfied that this would overcome the difficulty in the water supply for this school, you may arrange to have the pipe installed. If possible, the cost of the labour and material should be kept within your estimate of approximately $40.00.

Relative to the burlap required for the walls, I have to say that the Department will approve of having this burlap put on the walls of both classrooms and the two washrooms. It is noted that the cost will be approximately $105.60. If possible, this work should be carried out without unnecessarily interfering with the classroom routine.

You may arrange to have a suitable bookcase built, have it stained and varnished to match the woodwork in the school and supplied with lock and key. The cost should not exceed your estimate of approximately $34.00.

Please attend to the work in connection with the well before the cold weather sets in and the other work can be carried out when considered most advantageous. When all is completed, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

G. H. Sims, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,

Ottawa, June 13, 1926.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Garden River R. C. Indian Day School, states that the building should be painted, otherwise it will deteriorate very much. He also states that the woodshed is entirely too small and should be made larger.

I shall be pleased to have a report from you regarding the painting of this building, stating whether you would recommend that the work be carried out. If you recommend that the painting be undertaken, please give an estimate of the cost of the material and labour, and state definitely the amount of painting that should be done, also how you would propose the work should be undertaken. You should also report regarding the woodshed, giving an estimate of the cost of any addition that you would recommend be made.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

G. H. Sims, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
Sir,

Replying to your letter of June 13th ult No. 13-3-5 re repairs to R.C. School Garden River, I beg to submit estimated cost of painting the building inside and out.

Painting outside of building one coat of paint $145.00. Inside of building, sizing and painting two coats, Living room, kitchen, washrooms, classrooms, and burlap around kitchen. $148.00.

Extension of woodshed 30ft long by 12 ft wide in keeping with the present shed (painting included) $210.00.

I beg to recommend that this work be done, the school building will then be in first-class shape. I might also add that the shed is very necessary, as most of the wood remains outside during the winter and has to be dug out of the snow. I may say that I can get the work done for the above prices but if the Department wishes me to call for tenders I will do so.

I have the honor to be Sir,
Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Ottawa, July 7, 1928.

Sir:

I have your recent letter, undated, relative to the painting of the Garden River R. C. Indian Day School building and the erecting of an extension to the woodshed, also giving an estimate of the cost.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of having the painting carried out during the present summer holidays. You should arrange for the purchase of the paint, oils and other material required, obtaining competitive prices and making the purchase from the firm quoting the lowest. Please see that a good grade of paint, etc., is procured and arrange for the labour in having the work performed, under the direction of a competent painter. You should keep proper time sheets of the labour employed. A supply of forms for this purpose is enclosed. The outside of the building should be given one coat of paint and the inside, including living room, kitchen, wash rooms and classrooms, given the necessary sizing and two coats of paint. Burlap may be placed around the kitchen. You should select the colours of the paint to be used.

The cost of this work should be kept within your estimate, viz., $145 for the outside painting and $146 for the inside. Should you require an advance to pay labour, same will be sent you upon request, stating the amount required.

Regarding the extension to the woodshed, would it require to be extended the length mentioned by you, viz., 30 ft.? The Department does not desire to expend any large amount in the extension of this shed. I shall be pleased if you will submit another estimate of the cost of an extension, which should not exceed the length absolutely necessary. When we have further information from you in this connection, consideration will be given to authorizing the building of the extension. Please give this matter your prompt attention and reply as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

G. H. Sims, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Ottawa, October 18, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, enclosing a requisition from the teacher of the Garden River R. C. Indian Day School for supplies for the cooking and sewing classes and for hot lunches for the children during the coming winter months.

In this connection I have to say that the Department will approve of the teachers preparing and serving a hot lunch to the pupils at midday on each day the school is in operation and also teaching sewing, knitting, etc. You may arrange for the purchase of the quantity of sewing material as mentioned in the requisition prepared by the teachers, and you may arrange for the purchase, as required, of the various supplies and utensils for the serving of the midday lunch. It is not intended that a regular meal be supplied the pupils, as the purpose of the hot lunch is to augment the lunch brought by the pupils from their homes. It is thought that an expenditure not exceeding $15 per month would be ample during the winter months to cover the cost of the groceries and for supplies required for the serving of the lunch. You should arrange for the purchase of the sewing materials, utensils, and a sufficient quantity of food supplies to enable the teachers to start serving the lunch, and you may arrange during the winter months for the purchase of the food supplies as required. It is expected that the teachers will see that there is no waste of these supplies. Please forward certified accounts, in duplicate, covering the cost of the sewing material and cooking utensils, and also from time to time for the supplies for the midday meal.

If the teacher of the Anglican School will prepare and serve a similar lunch to the pupils at midday, the Department would favourably consider authorizing the supplies required upon receipt of a requisition for any supplies and utensils, etc., that may be required.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

MEMO FOR FILE:

On the 5th instant, I visited the Garden River R.C. Indian Day School and found a very attractive building, on a nice site, and a very interesting work being done by the Misses O'Driscoll and Hickey, members of the Order at Spanish. Next year, we should purchase 15 or 20 desks with rears and fronts to complete the two classrooms. We should also arrange to double the size of the boys' toilet and to install urinals. There are other improvements, which I am authorizing the Indian Agent to do, by letter of today's date.

Sir:

Pursuant to Mr. Ferrier's instructions, I have now to authorize you to erect a flagpole and a suitable sign at the Garden River R. C. Indian Day School. Building:

Ottawa, November 4, 1931.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Garden River R. O. Indian Bay School, has drawn attention to the condition of the drain from the cellar of the school building. He states that at the time of his inspection he took the trouble to measure the water lying in the cellar and that there was a depth of almost 4".

In this connection I would refer you to official letter dated June 23rd, last, in which you were requested to make an effort to find the cause of the trouble with the drain. It is noted that you forwarded an account to the amount of $24 for "digging up cellar drain and making temporary outlet for water". It appears from the Inspector's report that the work done to the drain last summer has not solved the problem and, as the present condition is dangerous to the health of the pupils and to the building, I would request that you give this matter further attention and report to the Department what you consider should be done to provide proper drainage and to prevent the water from getting into the cellar. You should give an estimate of the cost of any work you would recommend be carried out. You should also state whether this work could be done this Fall. When we have your report, consideration will then be given as to whether this work can be authorized at the present time or not. Please give this matter your prompt attention.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary.

At your request we have examined the premises of the R.C. School at Garden River and we are prepared to waterproof the basement of this building making it watertight for the sum of Sixty Six dollars ($66.00).

Sir,

In reply to your letter No.13-3-5 of the 4th instant with reference to the cellar drain at the R.C. School, Garden River, I am enclosing a letter from McLarty's Harten & Wiber Contractors giving the cost to make the basement waterproof.

I may say that when we dug up the drain last summer we found that the joints were fully one half apart and wrapped with tarpaper which had rotted and let in the sand, and it would be necessary to dig up the entire drain 400 ft. and lay proper tile with cemented joints. We made a temporary raft that time which took care of the water until the heavy rains in October.

Mr. McLarty who is a reliable contractor states that he is prepared to make the cellar waterproof by putting in a new floor and coating the entire cellar with waterproof cement for the sum of $66.00 which seems to be reasonable, and will I believe solve the problem.

There is at present only one inch of water in the cellar and I am having this taken out at once. Mr. McLarty can do this work as soon as the cellar is dry.

I would recommend that Mr. McLarty be given the job of making the basement waterproof for the sum of $66.00

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, November 14, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, with reference to the drainage from the cellar at the Garden River R. C. Indian Day School and enclosing a quotation which you received to waterproof the basement and make it watertight.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of your recommendation to make the cellar waterproof by putting in a new floor and coating the entire cellar with waterproof cement, for the sum of $66. You may, therefore, arrange to have this work carried out, and you should see that a satisfactory job is completed. The total cost should not exceed the estimate given by you, viz., $66. It is hoped that as a result of this work the difficulty occasioned by the water seeping into the basement will be overcome. Please arrange to have this work carried out at an early date.

After the work has been completed to your satisfaction, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Spanish Aug/33.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Would advise me whether it be possible to have the following for the garden near school—double bell, ladder and pool and suitable ladders in case of fire, some fire protection and enough lumber to have clothes closets in two rooms upstairs.

I may add that there is no fence around the school and this is a cause of much inconvenience as horses and cattle travel at will, furnishing a nightly melo de colo bells. If I am permitted to believe I could get some of the keep—grown up to get out of place. They for a very moderate price. If the wire could be gotten. Of course I shall await your advice on this.
and if you think well of it I can ask Mr. Sims permissin' to let me deal with the boys for the pots etc. The lumber for closets also can be obtained at very low rate from Turko Falls or Hallday and I could have one of their handy Indian men to do the carpentering. If permitted I could pay it off at I believe cheaper than by dealing in Toronto. Then I could effect the bill—They I mean only for lumber for closets & work on patios. Please express this note in a rush.

Yours very sincerely,

Ottawa, August 8th, 1933.

Dear Miss O'Driscoll,-

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to certain improvements required at the Garden River R.C. Indian Day School.

I am anxious to make things at the Garden River School as comfortable for you as possible, but our funds this year are so limited and the demands so heavy that we require very definite information regarding the expenditure involved before authorizing any repairs. When you return to the school, you might give this matter further consideration and let me have an itemized statement of the cost of each of the improvements requested in your letter. When this information is received, the Department will be in a position to decide what amount, if any, can be allowed.

Yours sincerely,

Miss C. O'Driscoll,

Sir,

With reference to his visit to the Garden River R. C. Indian Day School on the 25th ultimo, Inspector Greening reports, as follows:

"The toilets for the boys and also for the girls must be enlarged and repaired. I think it most important that this matter receive the earliest possible attention."

Sir:

I would recommend that the above changes be made the cost of which would be approximately $65.00.

I have the honor to be, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, giving an estimate of the cost of the painting and other repairs required to the Garden River R. C. Indian Day School building.

Dear Sir,

Will you kindly consider my request that the telephone be installed in this school?

The work connected with the school necessitates a considerable use of a phone to communicate with the agent and doctor in the interests of our Indians— and especially to communicate with the Truant Officer who lives two miles distant.

To do this, I am obliged to go to the store to phone from there. This is quite a little distance and here also I often find that the Truant Officer is not at home— thus necessitating much inconvenience, and I am obliged to make another trip.
If this favour be granted it will surely mean a great deal to me as it will be of great benefit in our work.

The approximate cost for school year would amount to $30 and the box costs $2.50.

Yours very respectfully,

Catherine Whisell
Ottawa, September 20, 1935.

Madam:

Ottawa, June 7, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, with reference to repairs required at the Garden River R. C. School.

When preparing our appropriation for the current fiscal year, it was possible to include an item of $75.00 only, for repairs and improvements at the day schools of the Garden River agency. In view of the present set-up of our appropriation, it is practically impossible to exceed the amount that was actually provided. Under these circumstances it will not be possible to expend $100.00 at the Garden River R. C. School. Please let me know what repairs are absolutely necessary at this school, in view of the fact that it will not be possible to do all the work suggested in your letter of the 4th instant.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.,
June 19th, 1930.

Dear Sir,

This is to advise you that I have inspected the Garden River R. C. School and the Anglican School.

The roof on the south side of the R. C. School is badly in need of repairs. I think that it needs to be reshingled. Also the cellar needs fixing as it floods after every rain and in the spring it is usually full of water.

The Anglican School needs redecorating inside. Also a new and better outside toilet is required and other minor repairs.

I would suggest that you give me authority to have a competent carpenter look over both schools and make an estimate on the cost of repairs needed to put them both in good shape.

Yours very truly,

R. P. G. Laurence,

Dear Sir:

Miss Louise Gattie, Garden River R.C. Indian Day School, has requested an allowance of $5.00 for spring cleaning. Kindly advise me if this amount will be granted.

She also requests that permission be given to have the fourteen school desks in the Senior Room re-painted and varnished as they are in very bad condition. The cost of this would be approximately $25.00.

I would recommend that this request be granted as the desks are now in very poor condition.

Yours very truly,

R.P.G. Laurence
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 6th instant I regret that funds at our disposal at the present time will not permit authorizing the expenditure requested in your letter in connection with the Garden River R.C. School. Might I suggest that the teacher organize the older pupils to clean the school without cost to the Department. These are serious times and all interested in Indian education are expected to co-operate as expenditure must be kept at a minimum. Consequently it is felt that the pupils should be sufficiently interested to assist the teachers in giving the class rooms a spring cleaning.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Ottawa, September 25, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Miss Burke, who called at this office today, is of the opinion that the interior of the Garden River R.C. School is urgently in need of paint. She intimated, also, that blinds are badly needed for the windows.

In this connection, may I refer to departmental letter to you dated July 8, 1942, in which you were authorized to buy certain supplies necessary at this school.

It would be appreciated if you could visit this school at an early date and discuss with the teachers, who will likely be there at that time, the best ways and means of decorating the interior of the school, so that the general surroundings will be reasonably attractive.

When you are there, it would be appreciated, also, if you made an inspection of the school grounds. Miss Burke is of the opinion that these grounds are wholly unsuitable as a playground but might be improved by levelling and seeding. You should send in a specific recommendation in respect to steps that might be taken to improve the playground surrounding this school. Your immediate attention to this matter will be very much appreciated.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. R.F.G. Laurence,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
October 3, 1942.

Dear Sir:

In accordance with the last paragraph of your letter 13-3-5, September 25th, I made an inspection of the school grounds at the Garden River Reserve R.C. School and found the playgrounds very sandy. I am of the opinion that the grounds should be seeded down as suggested to Miss Burke by Mr. R.J. Bryden, Soil Analyst, Ontario Agricultural College.

The cost of this work would be as follows:

Seed and Fertilizer required for the grounds, which are approximately 1/4 acre in area...........$20.00

Labour to level, roll, sow and rake grounds.......$10.00

12 loads of muck to cover whole area with a light covering, after seeding.....................$20.00

Approximate Total Cost..................$50.00

With regard to decorating the interior of the school as mentioned in your letter, I will report on this later.

Yours very truly,

At present a number of the children are using wooden benches and chairs and, in some cases, three boys sitting at a double desk. We intended writing sooner but the school work and problems we met with seemed to occupy every moment of our time.

No doubt you are familiar with the circumstances re the feud between the two bands. This made itself felt among the pupils and for a while there was "guerilla warfare" to and from school in active style. However they are most agreeable lately, and, at least among the children, the feud has died out or nearly so.

The single desks and the decoration of walls and ceilings has had a most subduing influence on both boys and girls. When the school opened in January, I was greeted with a chorus of: "Miss, is it ever nice" "Miss, it is just swell". We notice a much better and more cooperative spirit among both, parents and pupils, but punctuality and attendance are not up to the mark; at least not what we hoped for. Some certainly deserve credit for regularity and studiousness, but no amount urging or effort on our part can interest or waken up a few of the parents. As a last resort we sent the local constable around but I do not think they are afraid of him, perhaps the Mounties could help.

Our Agent, Mr. Lawrence, has been most considerate and cooperative. We had an understanding with him last fall that social evenings could be held in the school provided school property was not damaged and there was no rowdyism or drunkeness. These social gatherings brought us in friendly contact with the people and promoted good fellowship. Now we are annoyed by one of the Councillors, Mr. Williams, who claims he is a ward of the Department and tells us we are breaking "the Sabbath" etc. He intrudes even while the games or other entertainments are going on! I understand Constable Thibault has been active in breaking up their affairs when held in private homes, altho' I do not think he goes himself probably has his agents.
If the Department would notify those men to leave us alone we would greatly appreciate it. After all it is not their affair. We could never get around to all the houses, and the social evenings held occasionally give us the opportunity of meeting the people we would otherwise miss. It is not practical to hold them on week days, it would interfere with our class work.

I know my letter is altogether too long, but before closing I would like to let you know how much we appreciate the moving pictures held in the school. We had them for the first time on Monday. They have a decided educational value and bring both the children and adults in touch with the world's great questions of today. I hope they will continue to be given in the school.

Trusting I have not encroached too long on your time and thanking you cordially for all the help you have given us.

Respectfully yours

[Signature]

Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training
Ottawa.
Ottawa,
February 10, 1943.

Mr. R.P.G. Laurence, Indian Agent, Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

I have a letter from the Principal of the Garden River R.C. School in which she states that, while there appears to be a better and more co-operative spirit among both parents and pupils, the punctuality and attendance are not as good as they should be. This applies particularly to a few of the parents who do not seem to recognize the importance of sending their children to school regularly. Any assistance that you can give Miss Burke in this regard would be appreciated.

I did not expect the Entrance pupils to return, but we have a Ninth Grade. I am requisitioning just what is necessary. Would you please see that the books are sent at once. Or could I get permission to get what I need in the Sault?

There seems to be an epidemic of measles just now and rather severe, seems to be a combination of flu and measles. Many are out. I hope do not have to close school, but it may come to that.

Yours sincerely,

Ottawa, February 8, 1945.

Mr. R.P.G. Laurence, Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

I am in receipt of a letter from Miss S. Burke, teacher of the Garden River R.C. School, which reads in part as follows:

"We are snowed in almost to the eyes here. It took a man and relays of the school boys one whole day to get the snow and ice off the roof when I returned after Christmas. I wanted to have the snow plough turn in at our gate and make a road from the school to the highway and in turning make a circuit in the yard, instead of piling the snow up five feet deep at the gate. I did not succeed in getting the favour, but I don't see why it cannot be done. It takes the boys nearly a half day shovelling the bank the plough makes at both gates."

Miss Burke's request appears quite reasonable and it would be appreciated if you could arrange to have the snow plough do what she requests. I feel there should be no difficulty in arranging this with the provincial authorities who, I suppose, are supplying the snow plough on the highway.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Garden River, Ontario.

Mr. Philip Phelan  
Chief, Training Division  
Dept. of Mines & Resources  
Indian Affairs Branch  
OTTAWA, Ontario

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I have been wondering if you would consider heating our school by the crude-oil system.

The wood has become a problem; as yet there is no supply in for next year, which means wet soggy wood for the coming winter. There has always been difficulty along this line. One year we lighted the fires with heavy school wood and kerosene—a dangerous and disagreeable system. No light or kindling wood was supplied for two or three months. Another year the kindling was brought in six-foot length slabs from the mill, and lay out for over a month in the rain before I could get it split and sawed in stove lengths. During the vacation some of our wood has been stolen.

On the whole it is most unsatisfactory and has always been a cause of worry. Even when it is brought, it is often heavy and too large for the stoves—hence clumsy and so heavy to lift. Then it has to be re-split, and this costs high, as the natives do not believe in speed.

The crude-oil system is much cheaper and more convenient. The extra expense in procuring stoves suitable for the purpose would be paid in a short while. As far as I know, the crude oil stoves would cost about $125, each. We would need one for each classroom and a much smaller one for the living room. I forget the amount of oil needed for each room, but it was far cheaper than the wood.

Last summer you spoke of giving new floors. If you cannot give us both, I would prefer the crude-oil system to be installed.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6129, File 390-5, part 6)
Ottawa, May 6, 1946.

Dear Sir:

The Department is considering burning crude oil at the Garden River R.C. Day School. I understand it is becoming increasingly difficult to secure wood and that, as a consequence, green wood has to be used to a great extent during the winter months.

I have been informed that crude oil stoves can be purchased in Sault Ste. Marie for an approximate amount of $125.00. Three of these would be required at the Garden River R.C. School.

Please investigate the matter thoroughly and let me have a report from you. At the same time you should obtain a quotation for the oil stove and forward this for our consideration. The name and address of the firm quoting should be given.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
